oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Maple Dean Farm
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: 400 New Herman Rd, Shelbyville, Bedford Co., TN

Color photograph of a farm; large white barn with gable roof on left; barn has small windows on left side and on front is a large entrance, three windows, and larger opening near roof; on right is another white structure with a silo behind it; in the foreground is a wood fence; wooded and hilly area

Maple Dean Farm was established in 1819 by Thomas Dean. It began agricultural operations within the first generations of settlement in Bedford Co., established 1807. Thomas Dean was a prominent Democratic in Tennessee politics during the Second Party System. By the time of his death in 1881, he own 209 acres. His son Peyton Dean inherited it, and who later gave it to sister Elizabeth Dean upon her marriage to teacher Walter Crigler in 1885. The new Victorian farmhouse was constructed in 1886. It passed to Elizabeth's son John Peyton Crigler in 1911. John Peyton spent nearly a decade turning it into a model progressive operation, including the installation of electricty via a generator. In 1948, the farm was acquired by Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Crigler. And in 1976, Maple Dean Farm was certified as a Tennessee Century Farm by the Tennessee Department of Agriculture.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Century farms -- Tennessee; Family farms -- Tennessee; Historic farms -- Tennessee
